newsitem.title: PHILIPPINES: Philippine peso closes higher on inflows.
newsitem.headline: Philippine peso closes higher on inflows.

text.p: The Philippine peso greeted the New Year on a strong note on Thursday, finishing at 26.286 to the dollar from the end-1996 level of 26.299 amid strong inflows of foreign funds, traders said.
The peso was also buoyed by dollar sales by some banks which wanted pesos to cover their reserve positons, they said.
The day's average was at 26.288 from 26.293.
The peso traded in a range between 26.292 and 26.285.

"Most banks expected a stronger dollar," a dealer from a large bank said, referring to the fact that interest rates are expected to ease with the one percentage-point cut in reserve requirements effective on Friday.
Moreover, the imposition of the 20 percent final tax on term reverse repos would have discourgaed investors to invest in those bills and instead shift to dollars, the same trader said.
"The strong dollar did not materialise. Arbitrage money came in. They have a strong belief in the stability of the peso," he said.
As expected, the Central Bank intervened in the market. Traders said the Central Bank bought at least $25 million at rates ranging from 26.285 to 26.287.
A dealer, however, said the market may see a weaker peso on Friday as banks do their usual arbitrage play for the weekend.
The dealer said the peso may only weaken up to 26.315 since the Central Bank had been quoting an offer rate for the dollar at 26.318 pesos.
